posts.name: Tetsuya Cox
posts.cooked:
I am a programmer on team 2977. We are using photon vision to target apriltags for shooting into the speaker. Photon vision gets the best apriltag and I donâ€™t know how to change that.  I want to target the apriltag directly under the speaker, not the one off to the side. But photon vision gets whatever it sees better.

How can I target a specific apriltag?

posts.name: Rick F
posts.cooked:
Instead of calling result.getBestTarget() you can call:

That will give you the complete list.  You can then check the id of each returned target for the tag id:

Good luck!

posts.name: Tetsuya Cox
posts.cooked: Iâ€™ll try that out. Thank you

You could also try instead of targeting off of one tag, using a pose estimator to estimate the robot pose and calculate from there. This introduces more complexity but it also might lead to more accurate positioning data drawing from multiple targets.

posts.name: Tetsuya Cox
posts.cooked: When I use the code written below, it works to target the apriltag with a bigger fiducial ID. But when there is only one apriltag, The code crashes. is there a way around that?

posts.name: Tetsuya Cox
posts.cooked: Thank you for the idea. I will try that out as soon as I can get the robotPose working.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: Lists are zero based, so to get the first element in the list you should use index 0 . However, I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s any guarantee on the order of results, so I recommend checking all targets, and existing after you find one with the tag ID youâ€™re looking for.

posts.name: Tetsuya Cox
posts.cooked: How do I cycle through the list of apriltags photon vision captured?

posts.name: Tetsuya Cox
posts.cooked: Or how do I check the length of a list?

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked:
If youâ€™ll look at PhotonLibâ€™s Java API reference for getTargets() youâ€™ll see it returns a regular Java List , which you can find a description of all methods here:

declaration: module: java.base, package: java.util, interface: List

posts.name: Tetsuya Cox
posts.cooked: Thank you. That helped me a lot. I couldnâ€™t find the Java API.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
